articles.headline: Haiti Calls U.S. for Troops, After Wild Day of Gunfights and Suspicion
articles.snippet: At least 20 people were arrested in the assassination of the Haitian president — 18 Colombians and 2 Americans of Haitian descent — on a day of deepening mystery.
articles.abstract: At least 20 people were arrested in the assassination of the Haitian president — 18 Colombians and 2 Americans of Haitian descent — on a day of deepening mystery.
articles.lead_paragraph: After 24 hours of wild gun battles with suspects in the assassination of Haiti’s president, the nation’s authorities announced the arrests of 20 people and called on the United States to send troops to help protect crucial infrastructure.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff, Anatoly Kurmanaev, Catherine Porter and Julie Turkewitz

articles.headline: Biden Warns Putin to Act Against Ransomware Groups, or U.S. Will Strike Back
articles.snippet: Mr. Biden’s phone call appeared to be a pointed ultimatum to stop the hackers, who have attacked computer networks in the United States with relative impunity.
articles.abstract: Mr. Biden’s phone call appeared to be a pointed ultimatum to stop the hackers, who have attacked computer networks in the United States with relative impunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden warned President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Friday that time was running out for him to rein in the ransomware groups striking the United States, telegraphing that this could be Mr. Putin’s final chance to take action on Russia’s harboring of cybercriminals before the United States moved to dismantle the threat.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Who Paid for That Mansion? A Senator or the Haitian People?
articles.snippet: Valued at $3.4 million, a Haitian senator’s Montreal villa has become a potent emblem of the growing gap between Haiti’s impoverished citizens and its wealthy political elite.
articles.abstract: Valued at $3.4 million, a Haitian senator’s Montreal villa has become a potent emblem of the growing gap between Haiti’s impoverished citizens and its wealthy political elite.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — He is one of the few lawmakers left in Haiti, a close ally of the assassinated president who has kept his seat while the country’s democratic institutions have been whittled away.
articles.byline: By Dan Bilefsky and Catherine Porter

articles.headline: The Big Question of the 2022 Midterms: How Will the Suburbs Swing?
articles.snippet: Democrats and Republicans are already jockeying for a crucial voting bloc that soured on Donald Trump, tilted to Joe Biden and now holds the key to the second half of the president’s term.
articles.abstract: Democrats and Republicans are already jockeying for a crucial voting bloc that soured on Donald Trump, tilted to Joe Biden and now holds the key to the second half of the president’s term.
articles.lead_paragraph: PAPILLION, Neb. — Pursuing a bipartisan infrastructure deal and trumpeting a revived economy and progress against the pandemic, President Biden is trying to persuade the nation that Democrats are the party that gets things done. His message is aimed at holding on to a set of voters in next year’s midterms who could determine the fate of his agenda: suburbanites who abandoned former President Donald Trump in droves.

articles.headline: Global Tax Overhaul Gains Steam as G20 Backs New Levies
articles.snippet: The approach marks a reversal of years of economic policies that embraced low taxes as a way for countries to attract investment and fuel growth.
articles.abstract: The approach marks a reversal of years of economic policies that embraced low taxes as a way for countries to attract investment and fuel growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: VENICE — Global leaders on Saturday agreed to move ahead with what would be the most significant overhaul of the international tax system in decades, with finance ministers from the world’s 20 largest economies backing a proposal that would crack down on tax havens and impose new levies on large, profitable multinational companies.

articles.headline: Biden Administration Shows Little Appetite for Haiti’s Troop Request
articles.snippet: Pentagon officials noted that the request was broad and did not specify the number or types of forces needed.
articles.abstract: Pentagon officials noted that the request was broad and did not specify the number or types of forces needed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Haiti’s request for U.S. troops to help stabilize the country following the assassination of its president presents a difficult choice for President Biden: send forces to aid a neighbor even as he is trying to pare down America’s military footprint overseas, or refrain and risk allowing the chaos unfolding there to escalate into a refugee crisis.
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley, Michael D. Shear and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: How Local Guerrilla Fighters Routed Ethiopia’s Powerful Army
articles.snippet: A scrappy force of local Tigrayan recruits scored a cascade of battlefield victories against the Ethiopian military, one of Africa’s strongest. Times journalists witnessed the decisive week in an eight-month civil war.
articles.abstract: A scrappy force of local Tigrayan recruits scored a cascade of battlefield victories against the Ethiopian military, one of Africa’s strongest. Times journalists witnessed the decisive week in an eight-month civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAMRE, Ethiopia — The Tigrayan fighters whooped, whistled and pointed excitedly to a puff of smoke in the sky, where an Ethiopian military cargo plane trundling over the village minutes earlier had been struck by a missile.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh and Finbarr O'Reilly

articles.headline: More Power Lines or Rooftop Solar Panels: The Fight Over Energy’s Future
articles.snippet: The president and energy companies want new transmission lines to carry electricity from solar and wind farms. Some environmentalists and homeowners are pushing for smaller, more local systems.
articles.abstract: The president and energy companies want new transmission lines to carry electricity from solar and wind farms. Some environmentalists and homeowners are pushing for smaller, more local systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation is facing once in a generation choices about how energy ought to be delivered to homes, businesses and electric cars — decisions that could shape the course of climate change and determine how the United States copes with wildfires, heat waves and other extreme weather linked to global warming.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn, Clifford Krauss and Tamir Kalifa

articles.headline: 5 Pieces of Good News About the News
articles.snippet: A look at some of the ventures that have sprung up, fueled by a new sense of mission in American journalism and by the sheer quantities of money available.
articles.abstract: A look at some of the ventures that have sprung up, fueled by a new sense of mission in American journalism and by the sheer quantities of money available.
articles.lead_paragraph: My great predecessor in this column, David Carr, wrote at a time when the conventional wisdom was that the internet was destroying journalism.

articles.headline: Despite Outbreaks Among Unvaccinated, Fox News Hosts Smear Shots
articles.snippet: Months after Rupert Murdoch got a Covid-19 vaccine dose, one of his network’s stars, Tucker Carlson, called a Biden vaccination proposal “the greatest scandal in my lifetime.”
articles.abstract: Months after Rupert Murdoch got a Covid-19 vaccine dose, one of his network’s stars, Tucker Carlson, called a Biden vaccination proposal “the greatest scandal in my lifetime.”
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Murder Mystery: What Were Colombian Military Vets Doing in Haiti?
articles.snippet: At least 20 Colombians have been implicated by Haitian officials in the plot to assassinate the president. But their role in the killing, if any, is murky.
articles.abstract: At least 20 Colombians have been implicated by Haitian officials in the plot to assassinate the president. But their role in the killing, if any, is murky.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — One evening in early June, Mauricio Javier Romero, a decorated 20-year veteran of the Colombian military, received a call from an old army buddy.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz and Simon Romero

articles.headline: Hong Kong Migrants Seek Fresh Start in U.K. After Crackdown
articles.snippet: Many who have left the city say they feel less like refugees than trailblazers, eager to build a new home after watching their old one slowly transform under Beijing.
articles.abstract: Many who have left the city say they feel less like refugees than trailblazers, eager to build a new home after watching their old one slowly transform under Beijing.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Lin Kwong had a good life in Hong Kong. She taught sports management part time at a college and chaired an amateur drama club. Her young son, Chee Yin, was doted on by his grandparents. She had friends and favorite restaurants. But in February, she made the difficult decision to leave it all behind.
articles.byline: By Isabella Kwai and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Facebook Wants to Court Creators. It Could Be a Tough Sell.
articles.snippet: The social network is aiming to be a destination for creators and their viral memes. But TikTok and YouTube got there first.
articles.abstract: The social network is aiming to be a destination for creators and their viral memes. But TikTok and YouTube got there first.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the past 18 months, Chris Cox, Facebook’s top product executive, watched with surprise as Instagram came alive in ways he hadn’t seen before.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Taylor Lorenz

articles.headline: The Rationing of a Last-Resort Covid Treatment
articles.snippet: While ventilator shortages have been largely averted in the U.S., this lifesaving therapy is scarce. How to choose which critically ill patients get it?
articles.abstract: While ventilator shortages have been largely averted in the U.S., this lifesaving therapy is scarce. How to choose which critically ill patients get it?
articles.lead_paragraph: During a surge of coronavirus cases at Houston Methodist Hospital last summer, a patient in his 40s on a ventilator was declining. There was one more option, a last-resort treatment that can mechanically substitute for badly damaged lungs.

articles.headline: Florida, the Land of Gleaming Condos, Frets After Collapse
articles.snippet: The high-rise condos along the Miami seashore long embodied the Florida dream of sunshine and prosperity. But the Champlain Towers South catastrophe is obscuring that vision.
articles.abstract: The high-rise condos along the Miami seashore long embodied the Florida dream of sunshine and prosperity. But the Champlain Towers South catastrophe is obscuring that vision.
articles.lead_paragraph: SURFSIDE, Fla. — Modern Florida was built on condos like Champlain Towers South.

articles.headline: Hello, Content Creators. Silicon Valley’s Investors Want to Meet You.
articles.snippet: The online influencer culture is starting to draw serious interest from big venture capital firms. But the real money could be in digital tools, not the personalities.
articles.abstract: The online influencer culture is starting to draw serious interest from big venture capital firms. But the real money could be in digital tools, not the personalities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, Tucker Schreiber, a 28-year-old co-founder of a start-up called Combo that was building a video editing platform, noticed a lot more emails in his inbox. Though his company had no employees and no products, and hadn’t even said it was looking for money, investors were sending him a stream of messages.
articles.byline: By Taylor Lorenz and Erin Woo

articles.headline: ‘Everyone Has a Tipping Point’: Hunger Fuels Cuba’s Protests
articles.snippet: A day after a rare outbreak of anti-government protests in Cuba, the United States and Cuba traded sharp words.
articles.abstract: A day after a rare outbreak of anti-government protests in Cuba, the United States and Cuba traded sharp words.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hospitals and pharmacies have run out of medicines as basic as penicillin and aspirin. Blackouts have become maddeningly frequent and agonizingly long. Cubans lucky enough to have foreign currency wait in line for hours for staples like beans and rice.
articles.byline: By Oscar Lopez and Ernesto Londoño

articles.headline: E.U. Delays Digital Levy as Tax Talks Proceed
articles.snippet: The postponement came as Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen arrived in Brussels to continue pushing for a global minimum tax.
articles.abstract: The postponement came as Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen arrived in Brussels to continue pushing for a global minimum tax.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The United States secured a diplomatic victory in Europe on Monday when European Union officials agreed to postpone their proposal for a digital levy that threatened to derail a global effort to crack down on tax havens.
